channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for GA
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for GA

item.title: Report E-2023090717
item.description:
Report E-2023090717

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-28T15:12:07+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-13
  • City: ELLENWOOD
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 13, 2023, one (1) 6-gallon pail of UN3265 was damaged during transit and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. The crew identified the impacted pail and secured it in one (1) 55-gallon drum. The centralized the released material and collect the impacted solids with hand tools. All absorbents, debris, and PPE were contained in a separate 55-gallon drum. Both drums were labeled and staged onsite to be disposed of by R+L.

item.title: Report E-2023090585
item.description:
Report E-2023090585

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-25T03:13:31+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-19
  • City: CARTERSVILLE
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal NRG experienced a UN3266 AFCO 8714 Rave Hydroxy 50% release from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 4-gallons of material released to an 8’ x 5’ area of the trailer floor, and a 6' x 4' area of the concrete yard below due to a damaged seal around the port. Citric acid and water solution were utilized to neutralize the impacted areas and then cleaned with absorbents. The product was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with all cleanup debris into (2) 30-gallon metal drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.
